    The win ratio analysis of partially ordered data

    Multiplicative win ratio regression analysis

    wreg.Rd

    Fit a multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression model to partially ordered outcome against covariates

    Usage

    wreg(Y, Z, wf = NULL, sfun = NULL, ep = 1e-06)

    Arguments

    Y

    An \(n\times K\) matrix containing \(n\) observations of a \(K\)-dimensional outcome variable (whose components must be of the same variable type).

    Z

    An \(n\times p\) design matrix for covariates.

    wf

    User-specified win function for pairwise comparison. It takes two arguments \(y_1\) and \(y_0\) (both \(K\)-dimensional) and returns 1 if \(y_1\) wins, -1 if \(y_0\) wins, and 0 if tied. The default is wprod based on the product order of multivariate ordinal data.

    sfun

    The score function used in pseudo-efficient estimation (can be bypassed).

    ep

    Convergence criterion in Newton-Raphson algorithm. The default is 1e-6.

    Value

    An object of class wreg with the following components:

    beta

    A vector of estimated regression coefficients.

    Sigma

    Estimated covariance matrix for beta

    l

    Number of Newton-Raphson iterations.

    beta_nv

    Naive (non-pseudo-efficient) estimates of beta.

    se_nv

    Estimated standard errors for beta_nv.

    n

    Sample size \(n\) of input data.

    Nwl

    Number of comparable pairs (those with a winner and loser) out of the \(n(n+1)/2\) possible ones.

    References

    Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio for partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, Under revision.

    See also

    wprod

    Examples

    set.seed(12345)
n <- 200
Z <- cbind(rnorm(n),rnorm(n))
Y1 <- rbinom(n,1,exp(Z[,1])/(1+exp(Z[,1])))
obj1 <- wreg(Y1,Z)
obj1$beta
#>           [,1]
#> [1,] 1.0878509
#> [2,] 0.1113533
sqrt(diag(obj1$Sigma))
#> [1] 0.2018785 0.1941259
obj1$beta/sqrt(diag(obj1$Sigma))
#>           [,1]
#> [1,] 5.3886420
#> [2,] 0.5736138
